title: The Quintis interrogation of FBI agent Rhett Kessler
text:
Is it witching week in Australian funds management or something?

Hot on the heels of LHC Capital’s Russian roulette with suspended fintech iSignthis, Pengana Capital portfolio manager Rhett Kessler has publicly confirmed that US law enforcement taught him Jedi mind tricks 13 years ago.

Yes, the Federal Bureau of Investigation rendered Kessler almost undeceivable. “We are like the FBI,” he informed Bloomberg. Mercifully, though, “I make a conscious choice not to use it in a social setting because it’s very, very powerful.” Maaate, will you listen to yourself?

“We still get caught out,” he admitted, citing his 90 per cent success rate.

Well how’s this for a 10 percenter? On Livewire’s April 27, 2017 episode of Buy Hold Sell, Kessler threw his weight behind sandalwood fraud, Quintis (previously known as TFS Corporation). “We actually hold it … I think it’s a real business and very, very cheap,” he insisted, sitting alongside Quintis short seller Ben McGarry of Totus Capital. It closed that day at $1.21 and not three weeks later (on May 12), the stock traded for the final time. Pengana had itself a donut (unless it bailed in the interim – and we note it didn’t appear in the top 25 shareholders upon its suspension).

For us, Kessler’s most alarming defence of Quintis was that “the board … has done their due diligence, they’re all reputable people.” Surely no money manager would use the ostensible respectability of a company’s directors as a green flag?

Need we catalogue Enron’s board: A business school dean, the CEOs of several other companies, an economist and one of Britain’s foremost experts on accounting. All reputable people! As Marianne Jennings noted in The Seven Signs of Ethical Collapse, “Enron’s board was a model in corporate governance if it were to be judged by the standards of those who have given us the ideal board structure for effective corporate governance.” But then, see, Professor Jennings never trained with the FBI. That Kenneth Lay would not have fooled Kessler for a second. You can take that to the bank.
description: Pengana Capital portfolio manager Rhett Kessler has an unfair advantage: Jedi mind tricks.
